title: Christie's Settles Tax Claims for $16 Million
summary: Manhattan prosecutors say the auction house failed to collect sales tax on $189 million in private transactions. Christie's Inc. will pay up to $16.7 million to settle Manhattan prosecutors' allegations that the world's largest auction house failed to collect New York state sales tax on private sales for a five-year period ending in 2017.

title: The Fed's 'Main Street' Mistake
summary: The central bank's terms favor Wall Street and take new credit risks.. The essential facts of the coronavirus economic disaster are these: Federal and state governments have shut down most American commerce, robbing tens of thousands of successful companies of revenue through no fault of their own. Mass layoffs are already underway, with 6.6 million new jobless claims in the week that ended April 4, and cascading bankruptcies loom.

title: Paycheck Protection Rejection
summary: Democrats block a $250 billion refill of needed business loans.. The Paycheck Protection Program is more popular these days than hand sanitizer. As of Wednesday, less than a week after launching, it had claims on $98 billion in forgivable business loans, out of about $350 billion available. The White House has asked for a $250 billion refill, as figures show that 6.6 million more Americans applied for jobless benefits last week.

title: All the President's Ratings
summary: The Commander in Chief responds to our editorial.. Our Thursday editorial offering some friendly advice on how to make the daily White House coronavirus briefings more informative for the American people seems to have caught President's Trump attention.

title: A Recall Coup in Alaska
summary: A fight over judges turns into an attempt to nullify an election.. Proponents of good government often argue that nonpartisan systems to appoint judges will produce less-partisan courts. Then there's Alaska. The state's Supreme Court, which is currently deciding whether to allow a recall petition against Republican Governor Mike Dunleavy to proceed, is a reminder of the perils of putting judicial selection in the hands of a legal elite.

title: A Holy Week Amid a National Tribulation
summary: 'Hardship generally makes people stronger,' a social psychologist observes. What will we learn?. It is Holy Week. Easter is coming, Passover here. We are perhaps halfway through the big pause and fully conscious we are living big history. We've never experienced a time like this before-a global pandemic, a national shutdown-and may never again. When it's over most of us will look back on it as a life-changing event.

title: Lockdowns Won't Stop the Spread
summary: Stopping the coronavirus and protecting the economy are one and the same, but it is too late to do either.. The pandemic crisis now rests on a fulcrum. On one side is Covid-19 and every possible action that might prevent people from contracting and dying from infection. On the other side is everything else that matters: livelihoods that allow people to feed and shelter their families; civil liberties; the education of children; social well-being, including the prevention of loneliness, isolation and domestic violence; and all other medical conditions, from cancer and heart disease to dental emergencies. The belief that it is worth sacrificing anything and everything at the altar of flattening the coronavirus curve is foolish. But many leaders are behaving that way. We need a clearer picture of all that is at stake before those at the helm burn down the village to save it.

title: An Easy Coronavirus Foreign-Policy Win
summary: The U.S. could make friends, ease suffering and outmaneuver China by supporting African debt relief.. "If there is a crisis in the West, what's it going to be like here?" one resident of Dakar, Senegal, asked a pollster from the market-research firm Looka late last month. Many Africans are asking the same question.

title: Biotech Startups Expand Efforts to Combat Covid-19
summary: One push looks into whether Celularity's experimental cancer therapy also would help coronavirus patients. Celularity Inc., a biotechnology startup backed with more than $300 million in venture capital, is widening its battle against the coronavirus pandemic through a new agreement with United Therapeutics Corp.

title: Insurers Can't Cover Everything
summary: But they're uniquely suited to help distribute relief funds for businesses affected by coronavirus.. Businesses everywhere are turning to insurers to cover losses from the novel coronavirus. But their policies weren't written or priced to deal with pandemics. Lawmakers should work with the industry to help businesses, rather than trying to compel insurers to pay for the damage.

title: Keep Coronavirus in Human Perspective
summary: Death tolls don't capture the scale of the suffering.. I have claustrophobia, a trait I share with George Washington. The former president was so afraid of being buried alive, he insisted on lying in state at Mount Vernon for three days before being entombed. A sailing man, I've pictured myself tripping overboard unseen and sinking after a fruitless struggle. I am not at all like Melville's shipwrecked seamen, resolutely facing the inevitable by swimming down to their watery graves.

title: Faulty N95 Masks Hamper Hospitals in Need
summary: Desperate to protect staff from infection, hospitals and health officials are buying goods that often fail quality tests-and keeping them. Some hospitals say they are buying faulty imitations of the high-quality N95 masks workers need to treat patients with Covid-19, a new hazard for officials scouring the globe for scarce protective gear.

title: 'Is Europe Christian?' Review: Good Faith Estimate
summary: As European churches vanish, the struggle continues between Christian republican virtue and the new religion of desire.. American Christians are an individualistic lot. When they ask, "Is Europe Christian?"-the title of Olivier Roy's book, translated from the French by Cynthia Schoch-they tend to assume the way to answer it is to determine how many Europeans believe in the Christian message. The percentage of Christians in Europe will tell you how Christian Europe is.

title: Bernie Campaigns On
summary: He gives up on the nomination but is determined to make Biden unelectable.. When it comes to "fake news," we had a whopper this week. Voters were informed that Bernie Sanders was dropping out of the Democratic presidential contest. Joe Biden only wishes it were so.

title: A Coronavirus Easter
summary: The pandemic is a reminder that human yearning for faith is deep and abiding.. When President Trump said he hoped to have the U.S. "opened up and just raring to go" by Easter, he tied the nation's Covid-19 response to the ecclesiastical calendar. This was too much for some elites.

title: U.S. Exploring Coronavirus Testing for Food Plants
summary: The federal Covid-19 task force headed by Vice President Mike Pence this week discussed the prospect with meatpackers and food producers, according to people involved in the talks. The Trump administration is weighing a plan to provide coronavirus tests and other solutions to U.S. food-processing plants, as a way to soothe workers' fears and keep the country's food system functioning through the pandemic.

title: IRS Extends More Tax Deadlines to July 15
summary: Delays that were sought by business groups and preparers expand on help for individuals. WASHINGTON-The Internal Revenue Service has extended more tax-filing and payment deadlines to July 15, offering additional delays to help taxpayers and tax professionals cope with the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Chinese Doctors at Coronavirus Hub Say Evidence on Chloroquine Is Inconclusive
summary: One doctor sees promise for Kaletra-an antiretroviral drug for HIV-even though a recent study concluded it didn't work. WUHAN, China-Chinese doctors who have for months treated patients on the front lines of China's fight against the new coronavirus offered a sobering assessment of the potential treatments, saying they hadn't seen clear evidence that drugs such as chloroquine were effective.

title: State Farm Rolls Out $2 Billion Consumer Financial Relief Program
summary: State Farm's total brings amount pledged by top 10 sellers of personal car insurance to more than $7 billion. The nation's biggest car insurer, State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co., is slashing $2 billion of premiums owed on 40 million vehicles, making it the latest carrier to offer consumers a financial-relief program as auto claims have plunged under shelter-at-home restrictions.

title: New York Coronavirus Deaths Rise Amid Signs of Recovery
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo said state would add funeral directors to handle mounting fatalities. New York will seek additional funeral directors to deal with growing fatalities from the new coronavirus, officials said Thursday, as the state reported its largest daily death toll amid signs that restrictions meant to reduce the pandemic's spread are working.

title: U.S. Officials Target Chinese State-Owned Telecom Provider
summary: Federal agencies seek to revoke FCC licenses of China Telecom, a state-owned internet provider with assets in the U.S.. Trump administration officials on Thursday sought to revoke federal licenses used by China Telecom Corp. to do business in the U.S. as part of a broader campaign to curb global Chinese technology interests on national security grounds.

title: Bridgewater's Big Options Bet Helps Limit Losses
summary: A bet that would pay out if the stock market declined before late March was worth billions. A significant options bet by Bridgewater Associates that would pay out if the stock market declined before late March has made billions for the world's largest hedge-fund firm, helping to offset broader losses last quarter.

title: Verity Health to Sell L.A.-Area Hospital for About $275 Million
summary: Prime Healthcare Services gets court approval to buy St. Francis Medical Center out of bankruptcy. Bankrupt hospital operator Verity Health System of California Inc. plans to sell the Los Angeles-area St. Francis Medical Center to for-profit hospital operator Prime Healthcare Services Inc. for roughly $275 million.

title: Fed's Housing-Market Concerns Raise Pressure to Help Mortgage Firms
summary: Powell says central bank 'watching carefully' as firms brace for wave of missed mortgage payments. WASHINGTON-Pressure is building on federal regulators to help mortgage companies that say they face a wave of missed payments by struggling homeowners.

title: EU Finance Ministers Agree to Funding to Cushion Impact of Coronavirus
summary: The deal offers some unity after a tough fight among the bloc's members. BRUSSELS-European finance ministers worked through deep differences to agree to a package of measures totaling half a trillion euros aimed at blunting the impact of the coronavirus on the fragile economy, officials said. But a bigger conflict over whether to share the costs of the health crisis was deferred.

title: Joe Biden Seeks to Unite Democrats With New Policy Proposals
summary: Former vice president offers health-care and education initiatives that came out of conversations between his campaign and aides to Bernie Sanders. Joe Biden made an early effort to unite Democrats behind his White House bid Thursday, announcing two new policy proposals related to health care and education that came out of conversations between his campaign and aides to Sen. Bernie Sanders.

title: Navy Chief Open to Reinstating Captain of Aircraft Carrier
summary: Officials weigh findings of probe as more than 400 crew members test positive, with one in intensive care. The Navy's top admiral said Thursday he was open to the possibility of reinstating the captain of the USS Theodore Roosevelt, who had been removed from duty after issuing a plea for help with a coronavirus outbreak, once the outcome of an internal investigation is clear.

title: Peter Brooke Remembered as Founding Father of Private Equity
summary: Investor built two of industry's oldest and largest firms, TA Associates and Advent International.

title: U.S. Jobless Claims Soar for Third Straight Week
summary: Nearly 17 million Americans have filed new claims for benefits since mid-March as the coronavirus spread. The number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits continued to surge at unprecedented levels, bringing the total number of applications to nearly 17 million since the coronavirus pandemic shut down swaths of the U.S. economy.

title: Traders Agree to Settle With SEC in Hacking Case
summary: Two men allegedly traded on earnings information before disclosure to market. Two men accused of participating in an international trading ring that used stolen corporate earnings releases have agreed to settle fraud claims, regulators said Thursday.

title: SEC Steps In to Help Struggling Loan Funds
summary: Move seeks to encourage business development companies to continue lending money amid coronavirus pandemic. The Securities and Exchange Commission is stepping in to help out business development companies that have been battered by the recent economic turmoil.

title: Private Equity Sees Help in Fed's New Coronavirus Stimulus
summary: Buyout industry should benefit from $2.3 trillion Federal Reserve-backed lending program, experts say. Private-equity firms expect to have access to the Federal Reserve's new $2.3 trillion lending program, a relief for an industry that feared being shut out of stimulus spending designed to offset economic damage from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Stocks Log Best Week Since 1974
summary: Dow, S&P 500 climb 1% after the Federal Reserve unveils new programs to aid business. U.S. stocks soared Thursday to post their biggest week of gains since 1974, extending a remarkable rally despite evidence of increasing economic strain due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Freelance New Yorkers Can Apply for Unemployment, but It Isn't Easy
summary: As coronavirus pandemic batters businesses, the state's Labor Department is overloaded with claims. Freelance, self-employed and gig workers are now eligible for unemployment benefits, but many say the filing process is confusing and difficult.

title: Tobacco Giant Sues Rivals Over Patents for Cigarette Alternatives
summary: Suit is the latest move in the fight for share in the market for smoking alternatives. British American Tobacco PLC is suing two of its biggest rivals, alleging the IQOS tobacco heating device developed by Philip Morris International Inc. and sold by Altria Group Inc. infringes on its U.S. patents.

title: Fed Unveils New Programs to Support $2.3 Trillion in Lending
summary: Latest round of emergency measures expands central bank's footprint into credit markets it has previously avoided. The Federal Reserve is going farther than ever to shore up the U.S. economy, unveiling programs to lend directly to states, cities and midsize businesses that have seen revenues evaporate amid efforts to combat the novel coronavirus.

title: Fed Moves Spark Corporate Bond Rally
summary: Prices for debt from companies including Ford jump on Fed plans to buy bonds from so-called fallen angels. Investors snapped up the debt of car makers, oil drillers and other wounded companies after the Federal Reserve said it would lend trillions more to support the U.S. economy.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended April 4
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink Earned $25 Million in 2019
summary: BlackRock's bonus pool was largely flat compared with 2018, said people familiar with the matter. BlackRock Inc. Chief Executive Laurence Fink earned $25.25 million last year, a 5% boost for an increasingly influential figure behind the U.S. government's response to the coronavirus crisis.

title: You Have a Medical Issue Unrelated to Coronavirus. What Do You Do?
summary: For starters, don't assume doctors and dentists are too busy for you or that you can't get treated without an office visit. Many providers are handling a variety of problems via telemedicine. People across the U.S. are staying home and practicing social distancing to slow the transmission of coronavirus, but that doesn't mean they can put other medical issues on hold, too. Pregnant women require ultrasounds. Cooped-up preschoolers jump off furniture and fracture bones. People with eye diseases need monthly injections to maintain sight.

title: How to Make the Most of Your Telemedicine Appointment
summary: Get comfortable with the technology you'll be using, and have relevant medical devices and logs at hand. The coronavirus crisis has rushed the transition to telemedicine, and many health-care providers say there is no going back. They are finding that televisits can be more efficient than in-office visits for many types of medical issues, from postsurgical patients worried about infected incisions to rural physical-therapy patients who lack access to outpatient clinics.

title: To Keep Covid-19 at Bay, Americans Turn to Cleaning Services
summary: Companies deploy electric charges, sprayers and air scrubbers to give homes a deep clean. The coronavirus has changed what it means to clean.

title: 'Henry IV' and 'Much Ado About Nothing' Reviews: When the Staging Makes the Show
summary: Three streaming productions are among the most ambitious theatrical responses to the coronavirus. As America's theater companies start to grapple with the myriad problems of life in the shadow of the coronavirus, streaming video looms increasingly large in their planning. Many are now airing dramatic readings and newly commissioned short plays whose casts use videoconferencing tools like Zoom to perform "together" from their homes. Beyond that, forward-looking regional companies whose theaters are now closed until further notice are thinking through the implications of a harsh new reality crisply summed up on Twitter by the playwright Jeffrey Sweet: "It will be months and months before I want to sit in a room filled with strangers....My theory is that some of the theaters are going to switch to doing plays directly for streaming."

title: Cooking in Quarantine: Lemony Pantry Pasta With Kale, Chile Flakes and Garlic
summary: A wholesome, satisfying pasta you can have on the table in 20 minutes. This quick pasta is remarkably easy on the cook. Substitutions are encouraged based on what you have on hand. If you're swapping in a less-robust green such as spinach, add it later, along with the final toss of lemon zest and Parmesan. For a vegan version, bypass the cheese and add more olive oil in place of butter. Craving protein? Cook down bacon or ground sausage at the beginning, remove from the pan before adding the olive oil and garlic, then return to the pan at the end just to warm through. Whatever the variation, you can count on having a wholesome, satisfying pasta on the table in 20 minutes.

title: Coronavirus Batters Spring Home-Selling Season, as New Listings Drop 27%
summary: By comparison, new listings rose by an average of about 50% between March 1 and April 5 in 2018 and 2019. The coronavirus has hit the normally active spring home-selling season hard, as sellers across the U.S. press pause on listing new homes for sale.

title: Postal Service Warns of $22 Billion Hole From Coronavirus
summary: Agency already struggling with losses got $10 billion lifeline in stimulus package but says it faces far greater damage. The U.S. Postal Service is facing a precipitous decline in mail volume and billions of dollars in additional losses as it operates during the pandemic, where hundreds of its workers have fallen sick and a dozen have died from the coronavirus.

title: Coronavirus Brings New Sorrows to Holy Week for Queens, N.Y., Church
summary: Ill parishioners and the funeral of a beloved leader at St. Gabriel of the Sorrowful Mother weigh heavily on the East Elmhurst community. The coronavirus crisis has battered a church serving the immigrant community in the center of New York City's outbreak, infecting parishioners and killing a beloved priest.

title: Movies From the Past Still Deliver
summary: A trio of films are just what homebound audiences ordered.. At a time when the luckier among us can have takeout food and booze delivered to our doorsteps, movies about delivery services-"Deliverance" doesn't qualify-may provide flavorsome accompaniment.

title: Lufthansa Reassigns Finance Tasks Amid Sudden CFO Departure
summary: The economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic is putting a strain on executive succession plans. The economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic is putting a strain on executive succession plans, with some companies resorting to unusual arrangements to fill key vacancies. A case in point: Deutsche Lufthansa AG .

title: Pfizer Identifies Lead Coronavirus Drug Candidate
summary: Experimental medicine to be tested on patients this summer; arthritis therapy Xeljanz considered, too. Pfizer Inc. has found a promising but early potential coronavirus treatment, which the drugmaker aims to begin testing in patients this summer.

title: New Hampshire Voting Law Struck Down
summary: Senate Bill 3 required people to prove residency when registering to vote. A superior court judge struck down a New Hampshire law that required proof of residency for voters to register.

title: Oil Markets Cautiously Cheer Possible OPEC Deal
summary: Crude ends lower following a day of jittery trading despite prospects of a Saudi-Russia accord. Oil prices declined Thursday as traders weighed the impact of a potential deal among major exporters to cut production amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Edith Wharton's Former Oceanfront Home in Newport Fetches $8.6 Million
summary: Known as Land's End, the Rhode Island home was first listed for $11.7 million nearly a year ago. An oceanfront estate in Newport, R.I., that once belonged to author Edith Wharton has sold for $8.6 million after almost a year on the market.

title: U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson Leaves Intensive Care
summary: Johnson will remain in the hospital for monitoring. LONDON-U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has left intensive care following an improvement in his condition, a hopeful sign that he is set for recovery after being sickened by the new coronavirus.

title: Allies Wary of U.S. Stance on Huawei and 5G
summary: Europe has mostly declined to go along with Washington's hard-line position. America's global campaign to prevent Huawei Technologies from building the next generation of superfast internet has faltered on the continent where Washington finds some of its closest allies: Europe.

title: Amusement-Park Operator Apex Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Private-equity-backed business agrees to be acquired by lenders led by Cerberus Capital, subject to better bids. Apex Parks Group LLC, an amusement-park company whose operations are closed due to the coronavirus pandemic, has filed for bankruptcy with plans to be acquired by a lender group led by Cerberus Capital Management LP.

title: 'Mrs. America' Review: Over-the-Top Firebrand
summary: Cate Blanchett delivers a captivating performance as Phyllis Schlafly in Hulu's new series.. The nine-part "Mrs. America" is barely under way when you realize it's going to be actress Cate Blanchett's "Mommie Dearest." In portraying the conservative firebrand Phyllis Schlafly, Ms. Blanchett is hypnotically over the top, politely frenzied, a frozen smile atop naked ambition. It's a performance both fascinating and poisonous, as well as cartoonish, critical and, after a few episodes, addicting. That the series is being rolled out over six weeks, rather than all at once, might be for our own protection. Consult a physician, if you can find one.

title: Sizing Up Fed's Historic Intervention
summary: While market strain triggered by pandemic has eased, stresses remain. The Federal Reserve on Thursday rolled out another round of programs aimed at keeping financing flowing to an economy hit hard by the new coronavirus and related restrictions. Here are the highlights of Fed actions since the economic downturn began:

title: 'Baptiste' Review: The Familiar Comforts of a 'Mystery!'
summary: A plot-twist-filled 'Masterpiece Mystery!' production sees the return of the retired French police detective last seen in 'The Missing'. There's always a predictable, reassuring discretion about the long-running "Masterpiece Mystery!" whose various series are otherwise intended to befuddle. For instance: When the gentle old seashell-collecting pensioner lets the Romanian-accented meter reader into his seaside English cottage, and the visitor slips the plastic bag over the old guy's head, lays him out on the floor, and then takes out a chain saw, you know the camera will cut away before the real nastiness commences.

title: Car Makers Get a Boost as Chinese Plants Slowly Return to Life
summary: Global auto sales seen falling sharply this year, but China could be a lifeline. When China's economy crashed early this year, Western manufacturers with a strong presence there suffered.

title: A High-Stakes Divorce Illustrates How the Rich Play Real-Estate Tug of War
summary: A Houston billionaire is accused of using a complex web of trusts and limited liability companies to prevent his wife from accessing cash and the 13 homes they acquired together. In 2011, Texas financier Wilbur Edwin "Ed" Bosarge and his wife of 22 years, Marie Bosarge, used a trust to buy, for about $45 million, a flat on Belgrave Square in London, an area nicknamed "Billionaire Square." Mrs. Bosarge said she then set about decorating the home with the help of interior designers.

title: The Least Empathetic Thing to Say
summary: 'At least you weren't diagnosed with a horrible disease today.' Doesn't sound comforting, does it?. A friend posted on Facebook that her son's college had closed for the rest of the year: "He and his friends are devastated." I scrolled down to the comments. "At least he's not a senior!" someone offered. "My daughter will never get to go back to campus."

title: A Coronavirus Reckoning for the Left
summary: Progressives world-wide disdain workers and deride Sweden's moderate liberals for resisting a lockdown.. I have no idea whether Sweden's more modest approach to the Covid-19 pandemic-keeping schools and restaurants open while restricting visits to retirement homes-will be a success or a colossal and deadly mistake. No one else will know either, probably for months. But while we wait, the most interesting political fact about Sweden has gone largely unremarked: The prime minister resisting an authoritarian national lockdown and appealing instead to individual responsibility, Stefan Löfven, is the leader of the country's main center-left party.

title: What's At Stake
summary: A look at some of the estates owned by the Bosarges and various trusts, including a 27,000-square-foot chateau in Houston and a 72-acre private island in the Bahamas.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Church Is Closed, but You Still Can Confess at the Shed
summary: Coronavirus has canceled religious gatherings but hasn't stopped people from wanting to confess, especially as Easter approaches; 'We don't get this time off'. BOONTON, N. J.-Every other day this week, the Rev. Daniel O'Mullane has walked out of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, a gray stone church with a neogothic bell tower, and into an 8-by-10 tool shed out front.

title: On Developing New Drugs to Treat Covid-19
summary: In 1988, with massive protests from AIDS patients against slow FDA action, Dr. Anthony Fauci pioneered the plan of the parallel track.. In "Bet Big on Treatments for Coronavirus" (op-ed, April 6), Scott Gottlieb argues we cannot rely solely on isolation and social distancing and urges FDA to accelerate approval of new Covid-19 drugs. Yet Anthony Fauci says we must have conclusive clinical trials, which take months or even years, to prove drugs are efficacious. Remdesivir, the most hopeful antiviral, not yet approved, is an intravenous drug for hospitalization use. We need treatment before hospitalization. Favipiravir is a Japanese drug approved for treatment of Covid-19 in China, but not approved here for fear of causing birth defects. Yet we use several other drugs such as Accutane for acne, while carefully avoiding pregnancy.

title: Imagine Uncle Sam Airways' Final Landing
summary: If consumer choice is important for electronic communication, what will happen when there is only Amtrak Air?. Regarding your editorial "Welcome to Uncle Sam Airways" (April 2) and Daniel Henninger's same-day "The Next Coronavirus War" (Wonderland): Before the government nationalizes the airlines, it's worth looking at other industries that have been nationalized, specifically rail travel. Amtrak has lost money each year of its existence, so taxpayers who don't ride in trains subsidize those who do. With zero passenger rail competition, Amtrak has no incentive to improve its products or to lower its prices. Is that what we want for air travel?

title: Enlightenment Promoted Individual Liberty
summary: The foundational principle of Enlightenment thinkers from Locke to Hume to Kant (not to mention their student Thomas Jefferson) was that the legitimate purpose of the state was to preserve individual liberty.. In "The Coronavirus Pandemic Will Forever Alter the World Order" (op-ed, April 4), Henry Kissinger asks us to "safeguard the principles of the liberal world order," by which he means "Enlightenment values." He says "that the purpose of the legitimate state is to provide for the fundamental needs of the people: security, order, economic well-being, and justice."

title: Lockdown Baking Therapy Brings Rising Surprises
summary: I am staying home and baking bread, too. Sadly, I discovered that my rapid-rise yeast had expired more than a year ago.. Regarding "We've All Decided to Bake Bread" (Page One, April 3): I am staying home and baking bread, too. Sadly, I discovered that my rapid-rise yeast had expired more than a year ago. Because I can't dash out to the store, I baked my bread with the expired yeast. Lesson learned: The expiration date isn't always a truism, as my bread has been marvelous. And I still have five more packages.

title: California Hedge Fund Bets on Volatility Spike, Reaps 400% Gain
summary: LongTail Alpha funds capitalized on the markets' reaction to the new coronavirus pandemic. A California hedge-fund manager posted large gains last month by betting on the reemergence of market chaos.

title: Don't Count on the Locals
summary: The leadership in Latin American countries has almost always been nonexistent in helping their neighbors.. Daniel DePetris's April 3 letter "Wisdom About Venezuela Beats Feeling Good" states Washington can best accomplish a diplomatic resolution to Venezuela's crisis by allowing its partners in Latin America to help resolve problems in their own neighborhood. Have we seen that kind of help in the past? The leadership in Latin American countries has almost always been nonexistent in helping their neighbors.

title: Hedge Funds and Private-Equity Firms Given Warning
summary: Consulting firm Aksia says loan forgiveness shouldn't be going to many alternative asset managers. Investment consulting firm Aksia LLC has fired a warning shot to hedge-fund and private-equity firms: Don't take advantage of the federal government's $350 billion small business loan program or there will be consequences.

title: 'Virtual': A Way to Be Present Without Being There
summary: Centuries before digital technology and its use for social distancing, the term was used to mean an intangible essence. With so many people sheltering in place during the global pandemic, many of our previous face-to-face interactions have moved into the virtual realm. This week has seen families and friends gathering for virtual Passover Seders via video, while virtual Easter celebrations include online brunches, church services and even Easter egg hunts.

title: For Christianity's Holiest Week, Churches Seek Communion From Afar
summary: Religious leaders and priests adapt to coronavirus pandemic, canceling ceremonies and turning to relics and live-streaming of sermons. For the past several weeks, the Rev. Sam Rodriguez has replaced normal Sunday services at his Sacramento church with online versions.

title: Merck Venture Arm Invests in Quantum Computing Startup Seeqc
summary: German drugmaker bets that quantum technology could speed up pharmaceutical development. Quantum computing startup Seeqc Inc. has raised more than $11 million in venture capital funding from investors including a subsidiary of German company Merck KGaA, which is interested in using the technology for materials science and pharmaceutical development.

title: Why Michigan Signaled the End for Bernie Sanders's Campaign
summary: The senator's loss there was a microcosm of everything that had gone wrong for him for the past five years. The Sunday before the March 10 Michigan primary, a half-dozen Bernie Sanders aides sat sipping beers at a pub in Ann Arbor. One later recalled they were "sitting in awe" at everything they had done in the previous few days. They also knew it wouldn't be enough.

title: Morgan Stanley CEO Recovered From Coronavirus
summary: James Gorman is most senior Wall Street executive known to have been infected with Covid-19. Morgan Stanley Chief Executive James Gorman said Thursday he had recovered from the new coronavirus, the most senior Wall Street executive known to have been infected.

title: Now They Tell Us
summary: Virus mortality forecasts decline as economic misery skyrockets.. Based on the latest analysis from America's leading public health experts, politicians can stop comparing Covid-19 to World War II. But can their war on the U.S. economy be halted in time to prevent irreparable damage?

title: India Could Be Key Player in U.S. Effort to Thwart Huawei on 5G
summary: The country is allowing Chinese companies Huawei and ZTE to participate in 5G trials. NEW DELHI-When President Donald Trump visited India in February, he was expected to try to pressure Prime Minister Narendra Modi to join the U.S. in banning use of equipment from Huawei Technologies Co. in the building of India's next-generation 5G networks.

title: Franklin Prepares for Potential Chesapeake Debt Restructuring
summary: Mutual-fund company hires debt-restructuring lawyers as Chesapeake, pioneer in U.S. shale industry, faces coming debt payments. Mutual-fund company Franklin Resources Inc. is taking steps to prepare for a potential debt restructuring or bankruptcy of indebted oil-and-gas driller Chesapeake Energy Corp. , according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Disney's Stream Turns Into a Torrent
summary: The pandemic sends a flood of new subscribers to Disney+, offsetting some of the company's other shutdown problems. Baby Yoda apparently has staying power-especially when there is nothing else to do.

title: Iraq Names Another Prime Minister in Third Attempt to Form Government
summary: Political impasse hampers leadership grappling with oil crash and coronavirus outbreak. Iraq's president designated the country's intelligence chief as prime minister, the third attempt to form a government as political deadlock threatens Baghdad's ability to address multiple crises compounded by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Let's Go Back to Making Unrealistic Plans
summary: Maybe it's still too soon to pick a new date to visit Aruba. But we can hope.. A fellow senior-citizen student in my Spanish class announced in our Zoom video session last Thursday that he had just canceled his flight to Aruba and re-booked it for October. My immediate reaction was: "October when? And by the way, profesora, how do you say 'in your dreams' in Spanish?"

title: Want to Taste Wine With Authority? Try This Approach
summary: In the book 'Beyond Flavour,' wine pro Nick Jackson lays out his method of blind tasting. Along with a group of willing students, our wine columnist put his theories to the test. WHEN PEOPLE ASK ME how they can increase their wine knowledge, it's often because they want to buy wine with greater confidence. To become an all-out wine nerd, however-conversant in the names of esoteric grapes and little-known regions, able to identify wines in a blind tasting by their acid or tannin structure-is to aspire to an entirely different level of education. That's what Nick Jackson hopes to teach readers of his recently published book, "Beyond Flavour." With so many drinkers isolated at home, this might be the ideal opportunity to try his theories out.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Ships Head to Storage; Wavering Food Supplies; Digital's Long Reach
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain and Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Coronavirus Crisis Legacy: Mountains of Debt
summary: The government and the private sector are going deeper in the hole to survive the economic shutdown, which could be a drag on recovery if it spurs a period of thrift. The full impact of the coronavirus pandemic may take years to play out. But one outcome is already clear: Government, businesses and some households will be loaded with mountains of additional debt.

title: Sanders Ends Campaign, Paving Way for Biden
summary: Vermont senator's allies are encouraging the former vice president to adopt more-liberal policies. Bernie Sanders, the progressive whose two campaigns for president pulled the Democratic Party to the left, ended his White House bid Wednesday, leaving former Vice President Joe Biden as the party's presumptive nominee for the 2020 election.

title: Powell Pledges Aggressive Fed Action
summary: Central bank chief delivers remarks after unveiling $2.3 trillion in new lending programs. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said the central bank was aggressively using lending powers reserved for emergencies to prevent a temporary and indefinite shutdown of commerce from leading to a collapse of financial markets and the economy.

title: 'Sometimes the Crisis Makes the Leader': Andrew Cuomo and Five Lessons on Leadership
summary: Crisis-communications experts weigh in on how the New York governor is managing the coronavirus crisis. The nation is watching how New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo is handling the coronavirus outbreak, and it likes what it sees.

title: This Jobs Crisis Will Leave a Mark
summary: Even if the worst of the coronavirus pandemic is over next month, job losses could be prolonged and their damaging effect even longer-lasting. The novel coronavirus crisis has pushed millions of Americans out of work and it will lead to millions more layoffs before it has run its course. The sooner all those people get back to work, the better. The danger is that many of them won't be anytime soon.

title: How Rituals and Focus Can Turn Isolation Into a Time for Growth
summary: As the author learned caring for his ailing wife, a well-ordered day with close attention to mundane tasks can let us endure with purpose. These harrowing times are taking an emotional toll, even on those of us lucky enough to be hunkering down in our own homes. Our new reality-disrupted lives, fears of infection, worries about loved ones, the loneliness that can come with prolonged isolation-brings to the surface disorganizing feelings, from panic to despair, that a busy life might keep at bay. But there are ways to make this period of self-quarantine not only endurable but rewarding.

title: Chinese Growth Becomes a Tougher Sell on Wall Street
summary: Accounting fraud highlights corporate-governance concerns. After two accounting scandals in less than a week, the Chinese growth story will likely become a tougher sell on U.S. stock markets.

title: In These Gated Communities, Security Personnel Act More Like Concierges
summary: Resume Subscription. Michael Malone lives in a gated community staffed by former police officers, but the thought that they are protecting him from criminal activity has never crossed his mind.

title: Beyond the Gates
summary: Inside the home of gated communities around the U.S.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Surprising Strength of Eggshells
summary: Eggs, like bridges and churches, use the shape of an arch to bear heavy loads.. Springtime is egg time. They're everywhere: closely guarded in the nests of birds, decorated as gifts and filling the shops as chocolate Easter treats. An egg is a universal symbol of fertility and new potential, and their perfect curved surfaces give them an instantly recognizable shape.

title: Emerging Markets Need a Better Safety Net. It Already Exists.
summary: Central bank swap lines have prevented a global liquidity crisis. They could also pave the way to finally provide currency stability to developing countries. In the Covid-19 crisis, central banks' currency swap lines may offer a way to radically reshape the global monetary system while changing very little.

title: IMF, World Bank Face Deluge of Aid Requests From Developing World
summary: Scores of countries are asking for bailouts and loans from financial institutions with $1.2 trillion to lend. The health of the global economy comes down to a race between money flooding out of emerging markets amid the coronavirus pandemic and the efforts of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to pump money back in.

title: Canada Loses Over a Million Jobs in March
summary: The decline, adjusted on a proportional basis, is the equivalent to over eight million U.S. jobs lost. OTTAWA-Employment in Canada cratered in March, with over one million jobs lost, wiping away over three years of job creation in a single month and underlining the economic pain the coronavirus pandemic has swiftly delivered in North America.

title: GE Warns of Weak First Quarter, Pulls Forecasts
summary: Conglomerate says it can't forecast the duration of coronavirus disruptions or pace of recovery. General Electric Co. warned its first-quarter earnings would be below its prior forecasts and pulled its financial guidance for the full year, citing the disruptions and uncertainty caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: White House to Discuss How to Help Airlines
summary: Officials will brief President Trump on Thursday afternoon on their plans for assistance to airlines. WASHINGTON-Officials will brief President Trump on Thursday afternoon on their plans for assistance to airlines, which are eligible for grants and loans as part of a $2.2 trillion economic relief package, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Thursday.

title: The Bats Behind the Pandemic
summary: From Ebola to Covid-19, many of the deadliest viruses to emerge in recent years have the same animal source.. RaTG13 is the name, rank and serial number of an individual horseshoe bat of the species Rhinolophus affinis, or rather of a sample of its feces collected in 2013 in a cave in Yunnan, China. The sample was collected by hazmat-clad scientists from the Institute of Virology in Wuhan that year. Stored away and forgotten until January this year, the sample from the horseshoe bat contains the virus that causes Covid-19.

title: NHL Stars Get Social in the Era of Social Distancing
summary: The league is urging players to connect with the game's fan base during the current downtime to build more loyal followings. In American sports, professional athletes project an air of celebrity that often involves fashion shows and selfies with fans. Then there are players in the National Hockey League, the majority of whom could roam the aisles of a grocery store unbothered.

title: U.S. Surpasses 430,000 Coronavirus Infections
summary: Disproportionate impacts are seen for U.S. people of color; China lifts Wuhan lockdown; other countries extend shutdowns. U.S. cases of the new coronavirus grew to more than 430,000 Wednesday, as the country recorded its deadliest day yet.

title: Travelex Paid Hackers About $2.3 Million After Attack
summary: U.K. foreign-exchange company paid about $2.3 million in bitcoin to cybercriminals months before its business began unraveling. Less than three months before the owner of the world's largest chain of money-exchange shops unraveled in an accounting and governance scandal, it faced another challenge: It was at the mercy of hackers.

title: James Hartigan Rose From Passenger Agent to CEO of United Airlines
summary: Brooklyn native got early experience helping his mom feed 10 children after his father died. When James Hartigan was 12, his father died. The second of 10 children, he had a new mission: supporting the family. While finishing school, he delivered newspapers, worked at a bakery and a drugstore, and occasionally won cash prizes in bicycle races.

title: Are New Homes Becoming Old Hat?
summary: The premium buyers are willing to pay for newly built homes is slowly rising from a 2008 low, but it's still not what it was like 20 years ago, a new study finds. That new house feeling isn't what it used to be.

title: Farmers Dump Milk, Break Eggs as Restaurant Closings Destroy Demand
summary: Producers are throttling back as the virus erases sales to restaurants, hotels and cafeterias; 'It was heart-wrenching'. It was still dark outside at four o'clock on a recent morning when a tanker truck poured 6,000 gallons of milk into a manure pit on Nancy Mueller's Wisconsin dairy farm.

title: Key BP Deal Threatened by Buyer's Financing Snag
summary: Lenders are hesitant to back Hilcorp Energy's $5.6 billion purchase of BP assets. BP PLC's sale of its Alaskan business is in jeopardy after a group of banks balked at financing the $5.6 billion deal to buyer Hilcorp Energy Co. amid a historic rout of oil and gas prices, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: Smaller Cities Cry Foul on Coronavirus Aid
summary: Mayors protesting exclusion get sympathetic ear from some lawmakers for next round of stimulus. Mayors of small cities facing big budget shortfalls say they were unfairly cut out of the $2.2 trillion stimulus law, and they are drawing support in Congress to make them eligible for direct aid in future rounds of coronavirus legislation.

title: Europe Unleashes Massive Subsidies to Stem Job Losses
summary: Subsidy programs are launched across the continent to prevent widespread layoffs, with more than one million companies signing up. As job losses ricochet across the U.S., Europe is conducting an unprecedented experiment in navigating the economic fallout from the new coronavirus: Persuade companies to forgo layoffs by subsidizing private-sector wages on a massive scale.

title: Useful Homeschool Supplies That Go Beyond the Everyday Syllabus
summary: And aren't sold out-so far. Because at this point, a worksheet can only take you so far: WSJ. scoured niche sites and educational resources for under-the-radar recommendations to help shake up homeschool routines-or at least provide an analog alternative to screen time. From inventive supplies, brain-teaser toys and kids music that won't make you want to destroy your Bluetooth speakers, here's the best of what's out there (and still available) for your early learner:

title: Doctors Are Improvising Covid-19 Treatments, Then Quickly Sharing Them
summary: Blogs, social media and text-message groups are disseminating information and data to fight the pandemic. In mid-March, as U.S. hospitals scrambled for ventilators to treat a surge of coronavirus cases, a Vermont pulmonologist proposed a different treatment on a blog popular with emergency-medicine doctors.

title: Coming-of-Age Books That Offer the Perfect Escape Right Now
summary: Three grown-up notables share their favorite Y.A. books-from 'Harry Potter' to Judy Blume's 'Forever'-with enduring, ageless appeal. "Judy Blume's 'Forever...' is a rite of passage. As a teen, I had never read anything so honest about sex. I hid it under my mattress. Shirley Jackson's 'We Have Always Lived in the Castle' has a young narrator named Merricat Blackwood with an original voice that both boys and girls like. "I'll Give You the Sun" by Jandy Nelson is wonderful, as is Hayden Kimmel's 'A Girl Named Zippy,' an honest, funny, heart-wrenching account of growing up in the 1960s."

title: Coronavirus Clampdown Could Keep Some Candidates Off Ballots
summary: Collecting enough signatures to qualify for election has gotten much tougher in the age of social distancing. Candidates and incumbent lawmakers are facing difficulties getting the required signatures for ballot access during the coronavirus pandemic, with social distancing and stay-at-home orders making it hard for campaigns to approach people directly.

title: Pandemic Delays U.S. Women's Soccer Trial
summary: Pay-discrimination case against U.S. Soccer Federation pushed back six weeks to June 16. The coronavirus pandemic has pushed back the trial date of the U.S. women's soccer team's gender-discrimination suit against the U.S. Soccer Federation six weeks, to June 16, and the judge on the case formally acknowledged the federation's altered legal arguments after a controversial filing last month.

title: Pandemic Takes Toll on Mental Health
summary: Interrupted treatments, heightened anxiety and enforced isolation could cause lasting damage, especially to those with existing conditions. The battle to stop the coronavirus pandemic, fought with social distancing and enforced isolation, is taking a psychological toll that some officials warn could prompt another crisis, a mental-health one.

title: Las Vegas Job Losses Could Double Those of 2007-09 Recession
summary: Fear of crowds, lack of funds, likely to hobble tourism for years. Hector Padilla lost his Las Vegas house after the 2007-09 recession. It could be happening all over again.

title: Switzerland's Largest Banks Bow to Pressure to Conserve Capital
summary: UBS and Credit Suisse delay dividends as global lenders seek to preserve capital during coronavirus crisis. Switzerland's two largest banks, UBS Group AG and Credit Suisse Group AG , said Thursday they would pay 2019 dividends in two installments rather than in one chunk this spring as planned, as lenders across the world shore up capital to withstand the coronavirus crisis.

title: Coronavirus Hospitalizations Slow on New York's Long Island
summary: Officials keep boosting medical capacity but are hopeful region is approaching apex. The rate of hospitalizations due to the coronavirus pandemic has slowed on New York's Long Island after surging last week, but elected officials and hospitals say it is too early for the region to assume the worst is behind them.

title: Not All Food Delivery Options Are Savory
summary: Consumers are craving some delivery options more than others amid the pandemic. Nearly 30% of food deliverers admit to sampling food from an order, according to a study published last year by food-service distributor US Foods . Amid today's pandemic, however, the number of germ-infested touchpoints involved in a grocery store visit may be even more paralyzing for consumers. The choice has benefited some delivery players more than others.

title: A Season Without Baseball Could Be Crushing Blow for Minor Leagues
summary: The business model for the 160 minor-league clubs relies on revenue from ticket sales and the in-stadium experience. The 160 Minor League Baseball teams scattered across the country aren't financial juggernauts. Though they're part of the nearly $11 billion baseball industry, the average club has gross annual revenue of about $5.4 million and 21 full-time employees, who on average are compensated about $62,000 a year, including benefits.

title: Rationing Plans in Coronavirus Crisis Draw Growing Discrimination Complaints
summary: Advocacy groups say state guidelines illegally deprive people based on age, mental cognition or disability. State governments are facing a raft of complaints under federal law from a series of advocacy groups claiming that plans to possibly ration ventilators are discriminatory, pitting resource-starved hospitals against some of the nation's most vulnerable citizens.

title: Coronavirus Tests Viability of Home-Flipping iBuyers
summary: Zillow, Redfin and others stopped online all-cash purchases last month; some forfeit deposits. Ripple effects from the coronavirus pandemic are disrupting the burgeoning industry of online all-cash home sales known as iBuying, setting up the business's first major test in its brief history.

title: Haywire Immune Response Eyed in Coronavirus Deaths, Treatment
summary: Researchers are looking at treatments to suppress 'cytokine storm,' increasingly linked to the most severe Covid-19 cases. An immune system gone haywire may be doing more damage than the coronavirus itself in patients with the severest forms of Covid-19, doctors and scientists say, a growing theory that could point the way to potential treatments.

title: Coronavirus Capitalism Has a Darker Side
summary: As the coronavirus has spread, so has a new class of entrepreneurs looking to profit from the phenomenon. Want a face mask or some hand sanitizer? You might be able to get some-for the right price.

title: Coronavirus Disruption Puts Supply Chain Software to the Test
summary: AI firms adjust data, algorithms to better respond to Covid-19 impact. In late January, the artificial intelligence startup Noodle.ai began detecting coronavirus-related shocks to food supply chains rippling across the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Coronavirus Is Just Another Hurdle for Deutsche Bank
summary: Even with the most optimistic resolution of the current crisis, Germany's biggest lender is a long way from profitability. The time to buy back Deutsche Bank must be drawing closer, but it isn't here yet.

title: Don't Click! Coronavirus Text and Phone Scams Are Designed to Trick You
summary: Swindlers are taking advantage of the global health crisis, so watch out for email phishing, robocalls and "smishing"-text-message scams sent to your phone.. A text comes in on your phone. It's from the IRS, and your economic relief check is ready, pending your acceptance. There's a form to fill out. All you have to do is click the link.

title: Rural Hospitals Unsure Coronavirus Aid Is Coming
summary: Troubled health-care providers face uncertainty, red tape in getting federal funding under stimulus package. Embattled rural hospitals, some on the front lines of the coronavirus crisis, stand to lose out on billions of dollars in federal aid, with industry experts worried that financial lifelines could come too late-or not at all.

title: A Cop Who Tracks Mobsters Is Now Focused on the Virus
summary: Icelandic police superintendent put gangster duty on hold to trace people who may be infected and send them to quarantine. Police Superintendent Ævar Pálmi Pálmason usually tracks mobsters. Since late February, he has been on the trail of people who may be infected with the new coronavirus.

title: In Washington, Why the Predicted Coronavirus Surge Hasn't Hit
summary: The first state in the nation with a Covid-19 case used its head start with the pandemic to avoid a potential catastrophe. When coronavirus cases began mounting in Seattle in early March, Lisa Brandenburg, president of UW Medicine's hospitals and clinics, asked a colleague for projections on how many more patients she should plan for. His estimate came in several days later: More than 900 in a health system whose roughly 1,550 beds were almost always full.

title: Another Challenge for Small Businesses: Higher Card Fees Could Be on the Way
summary: Visa and Mastercard could raise some swipe fees, which would likely put a new strain on small retailers, grocers and others already reeling from the coronavirus. Many small businesses could have another thing to worry about when they come out of a coronavirus coma: higher credit-card fees.

title: Small Tennessee Hospital Faces Crunch Time as Coronavirus Hits
summary: Lauderdale Community Hospital climbed out of a financial hole in bankruptcy to find itself on the front lines of a public health crisis. Keeping federal money away from small hospitals that have survived against the odds isn't a smart move during the coronavirus crisis, bankruptcy lawyers say.

title: Hackathons Target Coronavirus
summary: Participants tackle global problems from the shortage of ventilators to how to enforce social distancing. Thousands of technology enthusiasts and others are flocking to a new wave of hackathons created to fight against the coronavirus pandemic.

title: A Month Ago, They All Had Stable Jobs. Now They Want to Work for Amazon.
summary: Amazon warehouses become haven of last resort as U.S. economy reels. One was an executive chef in Milwaukee. One was a small-business owner in Oregon. One managed merchandise for touring musicians. These three newly out-of-work Americans have one thing in common: They all recently applied to work at an Amazon . com Inc. warehouse.

title: Why Cabbage Is Making a Comeback-Again
summary: It keeps for ages, delivers an impressive dose of vitamins and adapts effortlessly to so many different styles of cooking. Here, a guide to buying it, storing it and using it in a range of delicious ways. CABBAGE IS ONE of those frumpy vegetables that had a brief but bright star-turn a few years back. Chefs of great renown began singing its praises and placing it at the center of the plate. More than a few journalists, inevitably, called it "the new kale." The spotlight, inevitably, moved on.

title: GOP Plan for Business Relief Meets Resistance
summary: Senate leader rushes to approve more funding for small-business loans, while Democrats also want more aid for hospitals, local governments. WASHINGTON-A Republican effort to quickly approve hundreds of billions of dollars in funding to support struggling small businesses' payrolls ran into resistance on Capitol Hill, as Democrats proposed a rival, broader plan to bolster the federal response to the coronavirus pandemic.
